Expectation1: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation1: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sit in my small room, the quiet hum of the convent broken only by the distant toll of the bell. My scripture lies open before me, the words inviting me into deep reflection, as is expected of me as a nun. Yet, my mind is restless. Mrs. Alvarez, a longtime parishioner, has asked to meet with me this afternoon. She’s struggling with her faith, and I know she needs my full attention and spiritual guidance. At the same time, as a citizen, I’ve promised myself to help at the free vaccine clinic this weekend—our community is short on volunteers, and public health is at stake. My tax documents are spread across my desk, needing review before the deadline, another civic duty I cannot ignore. The weight of these expectations presses on me: the parish needs my spiritual presence, the community needs my practical help, and the government expects my compliance. I feel torn, my heart pulled in different directions, unsure how to honor both my vows and my responsibilities as a citizen.
